> >- It's implementation-based (white-box) because you must be aware of
> the
> >implementation to decide when a sufficient coverage level has been
> reached.
> 
> I don't understand the second point. (Pause.) Wait, maybe I do. I use
> my knowledge of the current implementation that passes the current
> tests to decide what test to write next, if any. Is that what you mean?

Right. Imagine the simple case that the test passes although a certain
getter returns a constant string. It's obvious then that something in the code is
not perfect yet - a strong indicator for a missing test.

My point: The term "black-box" or "specification-based" has two aspects: 
(1) usage: only use the public interface of the component under test)
(2) knowledge: only use the specification of external behaviour to derive
test cases
Whereas (1) is at least a goal to strive for, (2) is IMO not valid for "unit
tests" as used in test-first development.

Johannes
